etymology: From the root ك ل م‎ (k-l-m).

text.raw_text: (transitive) to speak, to talk, to address‏لَا أُكَلِّمُهُ آخِرَ الدَّهْرِ‎lā ʔukallimuhu ʔāḵira d-dahriI will not speak to him to the end of time
text.text: to speak, to talk, to address‏لَا أُكَلِّمُهُ آخِرَ الدَّهْرِ‎lā ʔukallimuhu ʔāḵira d-dahriI will not speak to him to the end of time

etymology: From the root ك ل م‎ (k-l-m) in its original sense, "to use one's jaw", "to bite", "to chew". Compare Akkadian 𒄴 (kalmatu, “insect, bug”).

text.raw_text: ضَيِّق • (ḍayyiq) (feminine ضَيِّقَة‎ (ḍayyiqa), masculine plural ضَيِّقُونَ‎ (ḍayyiqūna), feminine plural ضَيِّقَات‎ (ḍayyiqāt), elative أَضْيَق‎ (ʔaḍyaq))
text.text: ضَيِّق • (ḍayyiq) (feminine ضَيِّقَة‎ (ḍayyiqa), masculine plural ضَيِّقُونَ‎ (ḍayyiqūna), feminine plural ضَيِّقَات‎ (ḍayyiqāt), elative أَضْيَق‎ (ʔaḍyaq))

text.raw_text: ضَيْق or ضِيق • (ḍayq or ḍīq) m
text.text: ضَيْق or ضِيق • (ḍayq or ḍīq) m

text.raw_text: to narrow, to tighten, to narrow down
text.text: to narrow, to tighten, to narrow down

etymology: Derived from the active participle of the verb فَنِيَ‎ (faniya, “to perish”), from the root ف ن ي‎ (f-n-y).

text.raw_text: فَانٍ • (fānin) (construct state فَانِي‎ (fānī), feminine فَانِيَة‎ (fāniya), masculine plural فَانُونَ‎ (fānūna), feminine plural فَانِيَات‎ (fāniyāt))
text.text: فَانٍ • (fānin) (construct state فَانِي‎ (fānī), feminine فَانِيَة‎ (fāniya), masculine plural فَانُونَ‎ (fānūna), feminine plural فَانِيَات‎ (fāniyāt))

text.raw_text: evanescent, transitory, transient, ephemeral‏تجاوز هذه الفانية‎ ― to leave this world, to  pass away
text.text: evanescent, transitory, transient, ephemeral‏تجاوز هذه الفانية‎ ― to leave this world, to  pass away

text.raw_text:
not (negating past tense)
See also: مَا‎‏لَمْ يَكْتُبْ‎‎ ― lam yaktub ― He has not written.‏لَمۡ يَكُنِ ٱلَّذِينَ كَفَرُواْ مِنۡ أَهۡلِ ٱلۡكِتَٰبِ وَٱلۡمُشۡرِكِينَ مُنفَكِّينَ حَتَّىٰ تَأۡتِيَهُمُ ٱلۡبَيِّنَةُ.‎‎Those who disbelieved among the People of the Scripture and the polytheists were not to be parted [from misbelief] until there came to them clear evidence.
text.text:
not (negating past tense)
See also: مَا‎‏لَمْ يَكْتُبْ‎‎ ― lam yaktub ― He has not written.‏لَمۡ يَكُنِ ٱلَّذِينَ كَفَرُواْ مِنۡ أَهۡلِ ٱلۡكِتَٰبِ وَٱلۡمُشۡرِكِينَ مُنفَكِّينَ حَتَّىٰ تَأۡتِيَهُمُ ٱلۡبَيِّنَةُ.‎‎Those who disbelieved among the People of the Scripture and the polytheists were not to be parted [from misbelief] until there came to them clear evidence.

examples.translation: Those who disbelieved among the People of the Scripture and the polytheists were not to be parted [from misbelief] until there came to them clear evidence.

examples.quotation: لَمۡ يَكُنِ ٱلَّذِينَ كَفَرُواْ مِنۡ أَهۡلِ ٱلۡكِتَٰبِ وَٱلۡمُشۡرِكِينَ مُنفَكِّينَ حَتَّىٰ تَأۡتِيَهُمُ ٱلۡبَيِّنَةُ.
examples.translation: Those who disbelieved among the People of the Scripture and the polytheists were not to be parted [from misbelief] until there came to them clear evidence.
examples.example_text: ‏لَمۡ يَكُنِ ٱلَّذِينَ كَفَرُواْ مِنۡ أَهۡلِ ٱلۡكِتَٰبِ وَٱلۡمُشۡرِكِينَ مُنفَكِّينَ حَتَّىٰ تَأۡتِيَهُمُ ٱلۡبَيِّنَةُ.‎‎Those who disbelieved among the People of the Scripture and the polytheists were not to be parted [from misbelief] until there came to them clear evidence.

text.raw_text: for what, why‏يَا أَيُّهَا ٱلَّذِينَ آمَنُوا لِمَ تَقُولُونَ مَا لَا تَفْعَلُونَ ۝ كَبُرَ مَقْتًا عِنْدَ ٱللّٰهِ أَن تَقُولُوا مَا لَا تَفْعَلُونَ‎O you who have believed! Why do you say what you do not do? Great is hatred in the sight of Allah that you say what you do not do.
text.text: for what, why‏يَا أَيُّهَا ٱلَّذِينَ آمَنُوا لِمَ تَقُولُونَ مَا لَا تَفْعَلُونَ ۝ كَبُرَ مَقْتًا عِنْدَ ٱللّٰهِ أَن تَقُولُوا مَا لَا تَفْعَلُونَ‎O you who have believed! Why do you say what you do not do? Great is hatred in the sight of Allah that you say what you do not do.

text.raw_text: second-person masculine singular active imperative of لَامَ‎ (lāma)

etymology: From Proto-Semitic *yad-, whence was derived the root ي د ي‎ (y-d-y).

text.raw_text: يَد • (yad) f (dual يَدَان‎ (yadān), plural أَيْدٍ‎ (ʔaydin) or أَيَادٍ‎ (ʔayādin)) (countable)
text.text: يَد • (yad) f (dual يَدَان‎ (yadān), plural أَيْدٍ‎ (ʔaydin) or أَيَادٍ‎ (ʔayādin))

text.raw_text:
an appendage of a body (as of an animal)
‏لِلْأُخْطُبُوطِ ثَمَانِي أَيْدٍ.‎‎ ― lilʔuḵṭubūṭi ṯamānī ʔaydin. ― Octopuses have eight arms. ذِرَاع‎ (ḏirāʕ), طَرَف‎ (ṭaraf)(of quadrupeds, literary) a foreleg رِجْل‎ (rijl, “hind leg”)(of primates, obsolete) the upper limb, the arm ذِرَاع‎ (ḏirāʕ)(of birds, literary) a wing(of a garment) the covering of the arm, the arm of a garment, the sleeve كُمّ‎ (kumm)(by extension) something resembling, likened to, or related to an appendage; including various technical elements perceived as an appendage:
pestle for a mortar (this is the normal term for it in Arabic) مِدَقّ‎ (midaqq), (also normal in al-Andalus) دَسْتَج‎ (dastaj)tiller of a rudderarmrest of an armchairhandle of an axe or hatchethandle of a quernstonetip of an archery bow
text.text:
an appendage of a body (as of an animal)
‏لِلْأُخْطُبُوطِ ثَمَانِي أَيْدٍ.‎‎ ― lilʔuḵṭubūṭi ṯamānī ʔaydin. ― Octopuses have eight arms. ذِرَاع‎ (ḏirāʕ), طَرَف‎ (ṭaraf) a foreleg رِجْل‎ (rijl, “hind leg”) the upper limb, the arm ذِرَاع‎ (ḏirāʕ) a wing the covering of the arm, the arm , the sleeve كُمّ‎ (kumm) something resembling, likened to, or related to an appendage; including various technical elements perceived as an appendage:
pestle for a mortar  مِدَقّ‎ (midaqq),  دَسْتَج‎ (dastaj)tiller of a rudderarmrest of an armchairhandle of an axe or hatchethandle of a quernstonetip of an archery bow
appendix_tags: this is the normal term for it in Arabic

text.raw_text: (of primates) the part of the upper limb between the wrist and the fingertips, the terminal portion of the arm, the hand كَفّ‎ (kaff)(by extension) the capacity to handle a thing, ability, power, kingship, ownership, help, grip, control, hand, dexterity, métier and so on

text.raw_text:
(al-Andalus, Morocco in the Middle Ages) a unit of measureflock of sheepa portion of a meadow snithen by two to three grasscutters or harvestmen in a rowa vine row of 30, 40 or 60 cubits depending on the terrain worked by four vignerons one after the other
the edition is bad and has been corrected here by Dozy, Reinhart Pieter Anne (1881), “يد”, in Supplément aux dictionnaires arabes (in French), volume 2, Leiden: E. J. Brill, page 849aa quire of paper رِزْمَة‎ (rizma), حُزْمَة‎ (ḥuzma), كُرَّاسَة‎ (kurrāsa)

an appendage of a body (as of an animal)
‏لِلْأُخْطُبُوطِ ثَمَانِي أَيْدٍ.‎‎ ― lilʔuḵṭubūṭi ṯamānī ʔaydin. ― Octopuses have eight arms.Synonyms: ذِرَاع‎ (ḏirāʕ), طَرَف‎ (ṭaraf)(of quadrupeds, literary) a forelegCoordinate term: رِجْل‎ (rijl, “hind leg”)(of primates, obsolete) the upper limb, the armSynonym: ذِرَاع‎ (ḏirāʕ)(of birds, literary) a wing(of a garment) the covering of the arm, the arm of a garment, the sleeveSynonym: كُمّ‎ (kumm)(by extension) something resembling, likened to, or related to an appendage; including various technical elements perceived as an appendage:
pestle for a mortar (this is the normal term for it in Arabic)Synonyms: مِدَقّ‎ (midaqq), (also normal in al-Andalus) دَسْتَج‎ (dastaj)tiller of a rudderarmrest of an armchairhandle of an axe or hatchethandle of a quernstonetip of an archery bow

an appendage of a body (as of an animal)
‏لِلْأُخْطُبُوطِ ثَمَانِي أَيْدٍ.‎‎ ― lilʔuḵṭubūṭi ṯamānī ʔaydin. ― Octopuses have eight arms.Synonyms: ذِرَاع‎ (ḏirāʕ), طَرَف‎ (ṭaraf)(of quadrupeds, literary) a forelegCoordinate term: رِجْل‎ (rijl, “hind leg”)(of primates, obsolete) the upper limb, the armSynonym: ذِرَاع‎ (ḏirāʕ)(of birds, literary) a wing(of a garment) the covering of the arm, the arm of a garment, the sleeveSynonym: كُمّ‎ (kumm)(by extension) something resembling, likened to, or related to an appendage; including various technical elements perceived as an appendage:
pestle for a mortar (this is the normal term for it in Arabic)Synonyms: مِدَقّ‎ (midaqq), (also normal in al-Andalus) دَسْتَج‎ (dastaj)tiller of a rudderarmrest of an armchairhandle of an axe or hatchethandle of a quernstonetip of an archery bow

(of primates) the part of the upper limb between the wrist and the fingertips, the terminal portion of the arm, the handSynonym: كَفّ‎ (kaff)(by extension) the capacity to handle a thing, ability, power, kingship, ownership, help, grip, control, hand, dexterity, métier and so on

(al-Andalus, Morocco in the Middle Ages) a unit of measureflock of sheepa portion of a meadow snithen by two to three grasscutters or harvestmen in a rowa vine row of 30, 40 or 60 cubits depending on the terrain worked by four vignerons one after the other
the edition is bad and has been corrected here by Dozy, Reinhart Pieter Anne (1881), “يد”, in Supplément aux dictionnaires arabes (in French), volume 2, Leiden: E. J. Brill, page 849aa quire of paperSynonyms: رِزْمَة‎ (rizma), حُزْمَة‎ (ḥuzma), كُرَّاسَة‎ (kurrāsa)
